newsitem.title: USA: Monsanto to develop cholesterol-cutting oil.
newsitem.headline: Monsanto to develop cholesterol-cutting oil.

text.p: Monsanto Co said Wednesday it signed a licensing agreement to develop cholesterol-lowering food products made from the oil of corn husks.

Preliminary studies by researchers at the University of Massachusetts at Lowell (UMass) indicate that corn fiber oil significantly lowers the amount of serum cholesterol and LDL cholesterol, the bad artery-clogging kind of cholesterol, in hamsters. UMass and the U.S. Department of Agriculture have developed a patented process to extract the oil from corn.

"What's been found with this oil is it has potentially much higher concentrations of cholesterol-lowering ingredients compared to normal vegetable oils that most of us consume when we try to replace saturated fats in our diet," UMass biochemist Robert Nicolosi told reporters at a press conference in Boston.

Monsanto will pay more than $400,000 in up-front payments and funded research to UMass. Potential royalties on revenues from future products and milestone payments will be divided by UMass and the USDA, UMass said.
Nicolosi said research into processing corn fiber oil will continue, and products could reach the market as soon as two years -- or perhaps in five to 10 years.

Charlie Hough, a business development director with Monsanto, said the company may explore a variety of applications for the product, but its primary use will likely be as a food additive or an alternative cooking oil.
"I think we're seeing this as a potential food product primarily," he said.
Consumers fighting to keep their cholesterol levels down could potentially use foods with the corn fiber oil in conjunction with popular cholesterol-fighting drugs on the market, he said.

No similiar product is on the U.S. market currently, Hough said. However, Finnish food group Raision Tehtaat Oy Ab signed a deal earlier this month with Johnson & Johnson to bring its own cholesterol-cutting agent Benecol, made from pine tree oil, to the U.S. market.

More than four million tons of corn fiber, which could yield about 80,000 tons of corn fiber oil, is produced each year as a byproduct, said Kevin Hicks, a researcher with the USDA. The fiber is now used as a low-cost ingredient for cattle feed and most of it is exported to Europe, he said.
